data.title: MGM/Hal Roach & TZ (Re: Paramount & Rawhide (5th Season 1962/63))
data.text:
On Tue, 9/25/12, Joe Pantaleo <joeandxander at yahoo.com> wrote:

markjcuccia at yahoo.com wrote:

Twilight Zone was still filming at MGM for the Spring 1963

hour-long season of 18 episodes, and even continued filming at MGM

for its 5th and final season (back to a half-hour) 1963/64. And

MOST of TZ was filmed at MGM since the very beginning (although

the "Where is Everybody" pilot with Earl Holliman was filmed at

Universal-Intl). A handful of TZ ep's were filmed at the

deteriorated-soon-to-be-demolished Hal Roach facility nearby in

Culver City,

BTW, I forgot to mention that there was an earlier pilot that was

written and/or produced by Rod Serling, called "The Time Element".

It did NOT air as "Twilight Zone" but as an episode of the anthology

"(Westinghouse) Desilu Playhouse" which ran on CBS for 1958/59 and

1959/60. Desilu Playhouse is not yet out on DVD, but I'm always

hopeful. The Untouchables two-hour or two-part (depending on which

version) pilot originally aired as a two-parter on Desilu Playhouse,

but was then compressed into a feature-film for theatrical release.

It is part of the first season volume one DVD of Untouchables.

The "Lucy-Desi Hours" (hour-long I Love Lucy specials) were originally

run as part of Desilu Playhouse in 58/59 and 59/60 (there were five

Lucy-Desi Hours that were stand-alone specials in 57/58 as well), all

13 Lucy-Desi Hours from 57-60 are available on DVD as the "7th/8th/9th

Seasons" of I Love Lucy.

And there were other pilots and special stand-alone broadcasts that

were originally aired as part of Desilu Playhouse....

Anyhow, "Time Element" was intro'd by Desi (NOT Serling), and was a

Desilu production, filmed at one or several of Desilu's facilities.

But it is considered a "first" pilot of Twilight Zone, and is a bonus

feature on the TZ first season Blu-Ray, but not part of the TZ DVDs.

The "Twilight Zone Radio Dramas" which began in 2002 does include

"Time Element" as one of its episodes though....

I knew the one TZ episode "TWO" (Charles Bronson and Elizabeth

Montgomery) was filmed at the Hal Roach lot and I thought that was

the only one. What others were shot there? And was the studio

still open for business in the early 60's?

Yes, "TWO" was indeed filmed at the deteriorating Hal Roach studio

backlot, also in Culver City. I think that "A Quality of Mercy" (which

MeTV reran just last night, Monday 24-Sept-2012) from the 3rd season

of TZ, might also have been filmed at Hal Roach.

Somewhere I read that Hal Roach's backlot was acquired by MGM at some

point, but fell into disrepair. It was demolished circa 1962 or so

from what I've read.

Hal Roach did produce several sitcoms in the early 1950s, and might

have still had a few in the mid/late 1950s (Gale Storm's second

sitcom "The Gale Storm Show" aka "O Suzannah" was a Hal Roach

production, likely filmed at the Hal Roach studios, but that might

have been about it for Hal Roach as a TV production company.

BTW, the TZ episode "TWO" with Elizabeth Montgomery (several years

before she was Samantha Stevens) used music score composed by Van

Cleve, which included a piece of music cue/score that CBS would

include their music score library, used in other TZ ep's later on,

as well as on Perry Mason (Case of the Surplus Suitor for instance

which aired on MeTV's morning run of Perry Mason yesterday), and as

part of the CBS Music Library, that segment of music score also was

used on several Fugitive episodes (which "borrowed" use of the

traditional CBS Music Score Library).

AND... that specific piece of music score I'm think of, which was

first used on TZ "TWO", was the THEME SONG for the 1974-82 "CBS Radio

Mystery Theater". And some "Twilight Zone Radio Dramas" since 2002

also include that "TWO" music aka "CBS Radio Mystery Theater" theme

song as well.

mjc

Somewhere I read that Hal Roach's backlot was acquired by MGM at some

point, but fell into disrepair. It was demolished circa 1962 or so

from what I've read.

The plaque at the former site of the Hal Roach Studios, dates the facility

1917-1963. It was placed there by the Sons of the Desert in 1985. Hal Roach

himself was present at the ceremony. The site is now home to Culver City Mazda

or it was last time I was there in 1990. Too bad the studio couldnt've been saved.

The Hal Roach Studios were demolished in the summer of 1963. MGM never took over or had ownership in the lot.

The little marker plaque is actually NOT on the site of the old studio property - it's on the wrong side of the (now elevated) railroad tracks. Culver City Mazda (now abandoned buildings) sits roughly on the site of the old Hal Roach Studios administration building that fronted Washington Blvd. If you were to drive on Landmark Street you would be driving through the heart of the old studio property, which basically went from Washington Blvd on the west to Wesley Street on the east, bounded by the railroad tracks to the north and it expanded to a somewhat erratic property boundary up against the residential neighborhood to the south.

The studio was also a LEADER in television production in the late 1940s and much of the 1950s, producing more hours of TV per week than any other studio at the time.

I'm happy to answer any other questions any of you might have about the studio, or the Hal Roach Ranch where the famous "Our Gang/Little Rascals" school house was located.

Probably in early 1963. By that time the studio was in bankruptcy and the physical assets were owned by a land development company (sorry, I don't remember off hand the name, but I believe they were located in Scranton PA). Anyone interested in the studio/corporation would be advised to read this book:

http://www.amazon.com/History-Hal-Roach-Studios/dp/0809327279

One of the most interesting things I learned in reading the book was that Hal Roach was trying to sell off the studio starting in the early 1940s! Television gave the studio a "second wind" so to speak.
